key_points: All federal prisons in the U.S. have been placed on lockdown ahead of President-elect Joe Biden's inauguration.
The lockdown affects more than 120 Bureau of Prisons facilities and began at 12 a.m. Saturday.
The decision was made as a precautionary measure in light of events around the country.
No specific incidents within the facilities prompted the lockdown.
The lockdown was not announced to inmates until after they were already secured in their cells.
Inmates will have limited access to showers, phones, and email, and can participate in basic activities.
This is the second nationwide lockdown, following one in April due to COVID-19.
Special Operations Response Teams are being relocated to Washington, D.C., to strengthen security.
A Bureau of Prisons spokesman stated coordination with the Justice Department for deploying as needed.
A potential case of tuberculosis at a federal lockup in Mendota, California, has also been reported.
spokespersons: Shane Fausey (President, Council of Prison Locals)
Aaron McGlothin (Local Union President, Federal Prison in California)
